Award.AwardTitle: Designing and Studying of Maker Oriented Learning to Transform Advanced Computer Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In a rapidly changing world, it is essential that students develop the ability to transfer and apply their learning in new contexts. This project, at Georgia Institute of Technology, will explore the incorporation of Maker activities into upper-level computer science courses. The project hypothesis is that maker activities will improve knowledge transfer, and lead to stronger undergraduate STEM communities who can better carry out interdisciplinary work. The PIs are concerned with the physical environment that is used for maker-oriented courses, and the development of a physical environment that will facilitate learning in addition to making. Project outcomes will include a model for the physical environment and artifacts that will support maker-oriented learning, as well as a framework for maker-oriented learning that builds upon previous work on problem-based learning and studio-learning environments. This project will be funded by the Division of Undergraduate Education through the IUSE and S-STEM programs.


The project will incorporate maker-oriented learning into two advanced computer science courses, Mobile and Ubiquitous Computing, and Human-Computer Interaction. The project team will utilize Design-based Research (DbR) methods to determine how maker-oriented learning environments facilitate skills transfer to new contexts, how maker-oriented learning activities encourage reflection in computer science learning environments, and how the structure of maker-oriented learning approaches impact the development of a community of learners. The project team will use observations, interviews, surveys, and data collected on tools and equipment to aid their iterative course design process. This data will also be provided to the project evaluator, SageFox Consulting Group. The evaluation team will use the ISE Informal Education and Outreach Framework, focusing on factors including understanding, engagement, attitudes, behavior, and skills, ultimately reporting on both the progress of the project team as well as the overall effect of the educational intervention on the students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many university campuses are implementing makerspaces to improve independent, discovery-based, and collaborative learning. Yet, few studies have looked at empirical data or the use of making in undergraduate classrooms. This research looks at the development and outcomes from maker-oriented learning techniques used in undergraduate computer science (CS) education at two institutions across four years. There were two primary strands of research: First, research in the classroom exploring how to fit maker activities into computing classrooms. Second, understanding how physical tools impact learning and the design of new physical computing tools to foster learning.

 

CLASSROOM STUDIES

Maker activities were integrated into courses in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) and Mobile and Ubiquitous Computing courses at Georgia Institute of Technology and across the curriculum for the Creative Technology major at Berry College. Georgia Tech is located in an urban center and considered a leading engineering school. Students taking upper-level courses, are very focused on technical skills and typically have little exposure to design or creative classroom activities. In contrast, Berry College is a small liberal arts college in rural Georgia with the new Creative Technology major established in 2013. Students begin taking Creative Technology courses after completing a year, or more, of liberal arts courses and typically, have had little previous exposure to technical skill building. 

 

At both schools, students perceive themselves to be better collaborators, more likely to apply course material, and more likely to generalize problem-solving strategies after the maker course. In comparing a typical HCI class and a maker-oriented class we found that students made statistically signiﬁcantly greater use of in-class reading material on the ﬁnal exam. These positive outcomes indicate that the iterative process of developing maker-oriented learning involving the community of learners, creativity, and physical spaces have generalizable implications for computing education in the United States. 

 

CS courses are larger than typical studio courses and many students did not view fellow students as a community of learners. Instead they viewed classmates as competition or as team members with whom they would divide and conquer projects. We developed interventions for students to engage in collaborative work and enhance their social skills. For example, critiques, which were initially frustrating to many students, were adapted by modifying the structure to having a few groups present around the edges of the room while other small roaming critique groups of would walk the room with an instructor. We also iterated on critique prompts and designed a set of playful cards which were successful in easing students into critiques.

 

Many students felt their creativity level increased because of the brainstorming sessions, critiques, and iterative design process. However, for others a life-long experience of being rewarded for following a rubric clashed with following a creative process. Future work to integrate making activities into CS classrooms should focus on talking to students about how creativity is fostered, how constraints can be used to leverage creativity, and how creativity is measured by the process. 

 

Physical spaces impacted the courses. At Berry College, where classes were taught in the makerspace, students established the space as their own and used similar to an art studio, for both work and community building. In contrast, at Georgia Tech, where courses took place in traditional classrooms, few students used makerspaces to work on their projects. To improve this, we dedicated class time to work in makerspaces and required students to complete the assignment in the makerspace. This improved the number of students visiting makerspaces but did not increase feelings of community. We also identified two approaches, the toolkit approach, and the workbench approach, for distributing tools in the class, which impacted the types of learning that took place and groups ability to work together.

 

PHYSICAL TOOLS

One unanticipated challenge encountered was with the tools used for physical computing, i.e. breadboards, microcontrollers, motors, sensors, etc. These tools did not facilitate learning and frequently caused cognitive overload. Students were spending so much time figuring out how to use the prototyping tools that they didn?t learn the basics of electronics, design, or integration of computing and physical artifacts. Over the course of three years, we conducted a series of classroom intervention, laboratory studies, and designed and tested prototype educational tools to improve the classroom experience with maker-oriented learning.

 

The data and analysis of these studies led to five main contributions: First, a codebook of the types of breakdowns within the hardware and software. Second, an analysis of the types and prevalence of obstacles, breakdowns, and bugs within the hardware and software. Third, insights into how the tools and their design characteristics contributed to the various issues and difficulties across tools. Fourth, identified novice work processes and strategies for debugging errors with the Arduino. Last, an account of how these types of experiences and tools are interpreted by novices who are intimidated by CS and electronics.
